Message.Title: Bo the Conqueror
Message.Msg: "Thank you Massachusetts! I am deeply honored for the opportunity to serve you in the United States" Last edited Tue Jun 25, 2013, 10:20 PM USA/ET Ed Markey ‏ "Thank you Massachusetts! I am deeply honored for the opportunity to serve you in the United States Senate." - EM

Harsh Texas Voter ID Law 'Immediately' Takes Effect After Voting Rights Act Ruling WASHINGTON -- Texas will "immediately" enact a voter ID law that a panel of federal judges ruled last year would impose “strict, unforgiving burdens on the poor," a top state official said Tuesday. The decision to go forward with a measure that those federal judges called “the most stringent in the country" comes after the Supreme Court ruled that a key provision of the landmark Voting Rights Act was unconstitutional. “With today’s decision, the State’s voter ID law will take effect immediately," Texas Attorney General Greg Abbott said in a statement. "Redistricting maps passed by the Legislature may also take effect without approval from the federal government.” In blocking those redistricting maps last year, a separate panel of federal judges ruled that the government "provided more evidence of discriminatory intent than we have space, or need, to address" in their opinion. Attorney General Eric Holder cited the Texas redistricting case in his statement criticizing the Supreme Court's ruling. Texas Gov. Rick Perry signed into law the voter ID measure and redistricting maps in question. Abbott took to Twitter to celebrate the death of the Voting Rights Act provision:

Message.Title: Snowden Ain't No Hero
Message.Msg: HE IS A TRAITOR plain and simple!!! He was entrusted with some of the countries most sensitive secrets and he betrayed this trust. If you think any of this information is new you need help, our government has always had ways of finding out what they want to. The problem was none of the agencies talked to each other which is why 9/11 happened. I personally have nothing to hide so I don’t care!! if you have nothing to hide why should you care. I seriously doubt the NSA or CIA care about you’re conversations with your girlfriend or talking about how your boss is an #$%$ or even if you hate Obama. They are trying to find terrorists and yes we have them here. Now on the other side do I totally trust what some of these organizations do no because they have no oversight with what they do. The facts are secrets are needed and the public does not need to know about every secret or black program that exists . I could go on and on but it’s pointless I only touched on a few things in this rant . For the record I do know all to well of what I am saying I did my tour with the government for a number of year’s and held a high security clearance. I will always say that anyone doing this type of whistle blowing is a trator and should be treated as such. HE DAM SURE IS NOT A HERO. My opinion

Message.Title: GOP won't get out of your bedrooms
Message.Msg: Ken Cuccinelli Appeals To Defend Virginia's Anti-Sodomy Law At Supreme Court WASHINGTON -- Virginia Attorney General Ken Cuccinelli, the GOP's 2013 gubernatorial candidate, filed a petition Tuesday with the U.S. Supreme Court seeking to uphold Virginia's anti-sodomy law. Cuccinelli wants the court to reconsider a March 2013 decision by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 4th Circuit striking down the state's "crimes against nature" statute. The 4th Circuit ruled that the law did not pass muster in light of the Supreme Court's 2003 Lawrence v. Texas decision, which struck down the latter state's anti-sodomy law as an unconstitutional criminalization of Americans' sexual conduct. The Virginia law, however, remained on the books. The 4th Circuit ruled in favor of William Scott McDonald, who was convicted in 2005 at age 47 under the Virginia statute for soliciting a 17-year-old girl to commit sodomy. That law broadly makes oral and anal sex a Class 6 felony. While such laws historically targeted gay men, they have also been used against heterosexual activity. The three-judge panel ruled that an unconstitutional law could not be used to convict McDonald. It added that the Virginia Legislature could pass another law to criminalize sexual conduct specifically between a minor and an adult. The Lawrence ruling applied only to consensual adult conduct.

More importantly he violated the Sacred Code of the Sysadmin . . . root access is not to be abused, or used to spy on one's employers, or to create networks within the network for private use without the bosses permission. Which, in this case, it's fairly safe to assume from all the documents he had to sign that he didn't have it, wouldn't get it, and they'd have been horrified to learn he was even READING the material except in the course of debugging, optimization, etc, having to do with system performance issues. Any disclosures he got were supposed to be of what we'd call the "incidental" kind, things he'd have to know to do his job, but didn't have full clearance for. Fortunately it's doubtful he breached the seriously secure portions of the network, but he certainly got well into the outer perimeter. I think what bothers the NSA most are questions as to what ELSE he might have done, as they fully are aware of what THEY could have done given the same access. Snowden no doubt has gigabytes of information he can neither read or decode stashed away somewhere waiting for a leap in quantum computing to help crack it. What he is releasing is what he read in the clear (lower classification level) or was told about. Who here really doubted the NSA wasn't t'ing all international router traffic to other servers for analysis? I mean that's just a given. That's they're ALSO monitoring the national backbone is surprising, but I guess once you have the computer power available to do it, it's just another extension of the same idea.

funny, you are such a stodgy ignoramus and fearful wienie that I assumed you were very old and off your rocker, so I used an example you might understand. Most young people understand the meaning of metadata. You seem to think it is something that anyone could use...... the fact is that unless the nsa PROGRAMMED a search to find something specific ,YOUR metadata could never be found.... get it?.... its just numbers and times and routing info...... the NSA is LOOKING for links to KNOWN terrorist numbers..... so they search for THAT in the pile of trillions of connection data..............get it? so.... If YOUR numbers come up from a search of links to KNOWN terrorists.... a warrant could be obtained.... and then and only then would the details of YOUR metadata become known to a person...............get it?

"Amy Howe: Here's a Plain English take on United States v. Windsor, the DOMA case: The federal Defense of Marriage Act defines "marriage," for purposes of over a thousand federal laws and programs, as a union between a man and a woman only. Today the Court ruled, by a vote of five to four, in an opinion by Justice Kennedy, that the law is unconstitutional. The Court explained that the states have long had the responsibility of regulating and defining marriage, and some states have opted to allow same-sex couples to marry to give them the protection and dignity associated with marriage. By denying recognition to same-sex couples who are legally married, federal law discriminates against them to express disapproval of state-sanctioned same-sex marriage. This decision means that same-sex couples who are legally married must now be treated the same under federal law as married opposite-sex couples."

Message.Title: ETFC Green Lights
Message.Msg: ETFC Green Lights * Ken gone * Moon no longer posting every 2 minutes and going short * Below 10B in total loans left * Housing picking up pace * Interest rates getting ready to rise * Huge reserves * Super low stock price - priced like BK when everything looks excellent now * Buyout could happen at anytime...company cleaned up

I wouldn't be surprised, even I sold off my short term shares on hopes that some devil will hammer it back down to try to sucker more folks into shorting or buying PUTS. Thus letting me repurchase my position at a discount. I've made enough money doing this back and forth thing just this last year to totally offset my unrealized losses in this stock. Almost every Yo-yo is, for me, a Yo! I've got 1500 long term shares (yeah the ones that went long term this month) and 25 LEAP contracts that I'll hold long term, some other companies shares that are long term, but everything else is up to play around with. I probably wouldn't have sold if Apple hadn't gone sour and taken away my unrealized gains there.

Because if I can't take advantage of a potential steal no reason someone here shouldn't. Options, particularly thinly traded ones, only rarely get opportunities to buy that far inside the real option value, and sometimes offers only are active for so long in the queue before either another investor or the market maker takes them off through sale or cancellation. BTW, is more than ONE buy rating . . . some companies have changed sentiment, you should check that out . . .
